newsitem.title: RUSSIA: January 1 is deadline to pay wage debts - Yeltsin.
newsitem.headline: January 1 is deadline to pay wage debts - Yeltsin.

text.p: President Boris Yeltsin ordered on Tuesday that wage debts to the armed forces should be paid in two months and the rest of the backlog to others on the state payroll by January 1, 1998, Russian news agencies said.

Yeltsin said last week he wanted all the debts to be paid by October 1 but senior ministers appeared to have persuaded the 66-year-old leader the task was not realistic. The overall sum of the debt was not immediately avaliable.

Last week Yeltsin gave the cabinet three months to pay back all public-sector wage arrears but two leading reformers in the government, first deputy prime ministers Boris Nemtsov and Anatoly Chubais, said the deadline was too tight. Chubais is also finance minister.
Yeltsin's decree was signed after he met Nemtsov and other top government officials at his holiday retreat in the northwestern region of Karelia.

"We must determine ways to find finances...how we can cut spending and increase revenues, where to use borrowing, the sale of property and securities," Interfax news agency quoted Yeltsin as saying during the meeting.

Russian news agencies said Yeltsin also signed decrees on production sharing and on oil industry's debts to the state budget. No details were immediately available but Interfax quoted Yeltsin as saying both documents were "of global importance".
